 This is a perfectly valid observation. However, according to the definition that you gave in your original proposal, there was no definite plan, order, or purpose for that card to be on top. This qualifies as random.
 This is also precisely why I very much wanted to clarify your use of the word "random." Your defense of the "No such thing as random" idea is disingenuous to the definition of random. Perhaps you could find a different word to use? (Unfortunately, I can't seem to think of an appropriate one.)
 
 Now the more complicated part:
 
 
Assuming we could in fact observe the decay and repeat the experiment with the exact same conditions and variables we would assume we would see a pattern of with atom would decay first.

 This is simply not the case. All ten atoms will appear identical until one decays. If we ran two side-by-side experiments, each with the ten atoms arranged linearly, we cannot "assume" (or rather, predict) that if atom #3 decays first in experiment A, that atom #3 in experiment B will decay before its peers.
 The probability that atom #n of both experiments A and B will decay first has a probability of 10%. That is, we can indeed conclude odds, but we cannot predict outcome.
 Predicting the elapsed times at which any of these atoms decay is another beast altogether.
 
 Let us simplify this scenario further. Imagine you have a single atom of U-235. (Or pick a radioactive species with a shorter half-life; the concept is identical.) You may make as many observations as you wish. However, at some point, you must be able to repeatably predict when any certain atom will decay.
 
 Based on my understanding of radioactive decay, I predict that you won't be able to do it.

In fact, it is impossible to predict the outcome any time, it just so happens that roughly 50% of the time you will guess correctly because of probability.
